question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('bb92f6d7-86d2-45b6-b4ed-0291f567eb4d'), title='Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('e8e5e2ca-865d-4102-9b07-17caf1298bf1'), title='Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

(2) Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference?', body='This market will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024, and (2) Elon Musk makes a public statement regarding Bitcoin that is widely reported in the media before July 25, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('84eb6b39-e48f-4f1a-9d09-b79458dd0f80'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? (b) Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference?', body='This market will resolve YES if either of the following occurs: (1) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024; (2) Elon Musk makes a public statement regarding Bitcoin that is widely reported in the media before July 25, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('e71b2fb8-bb84-4a2f-a7de-fce57813169a'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a public statement about Bitcoin that is widely reported in the media before July 25, 2024, and (2) Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This question will resolve YES if (1) Elon Musk makes a public statement regarding Bitcoin that is widely reported in the media before July 25, 2024, and (2) Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('0cec97f7-02a7-4c43-9893-0a18e44c18e5'), title='Given that Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public statement about Bitcoin before the conference?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024. This question will resolve YES if Elon Musk makes a public statement regarding Bitcoin that is widely reported in the media before July 25, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 29, 12, 42, 14, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
metadata.chain_of_thought:
RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE

0.73

RECEIVED

For the event of Elon Musk showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, I would consider several factors such as his past attendance at similar events, his current involvement with Bitcoin, and any public statements he may have made regarding his plans for the conference. Given his active engagement with the cryptocurrency community, I would assign a relatively high probability to P (showing up) and a correspondingly lower probability to not_P. 

When considering para_P, which is essentially the same event as P, I would assign it the same probability since it is asking the same question in a different format.

For Q, which involves Musk making a public statement about Bitcoin before the conference, I would evaluate his recent social media activity and any upcoming statements he might make. If he has been vocal about Bitcoin recently, I would assign a moderate probability to Q.

In terms of the relationships between these events, P and Q are somewhat independent but can influence each other; if Musk shows up at the conference, it may increase the likelihood of him making a statement about Bitcoin. Therefore, I would expect P_and_Q (both events happening) to be less than the individual probabilities of P and Q, since both events happening together is a more specific scenario.

P_or_Q would be higher than either P or Q alone, as it encompasses the possibility of either event occurring. 

Q_and_not_P would be a unique scenario where Musk makes a statement but does not show up, which I would assign a lower probability to, as his attendance may correlate with making a statement. 

Lastly, Q_given_P would be expected to be higher than Q alone, as the premise of him showing up could increase the likelihood of him making a statement. 

Overall, I would ensure that the probabilities assigned to each event adhere to the consistency rules provided, adjusting them as necessary to ensure that all relationships hold true mathematically.

not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.60,
P_and_Q: 0.50,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.10,
Q_given_P: 0.70

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.75 + 0.50 - 0.60 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.60 - 1, 0) <= 0.50 <= min(0.65, 0.60) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.60) <= 0.75 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.60) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.75 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.50 / 0.70 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

Q: 0.60,

In evaluating the probabilities for the questions regarding Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and his potential public statements about Bitcoin, I consider a few factors. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's prior engagements and interests in Bitcoin. Given his history with cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend, let's say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a chance that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question essentially mirrors P, so I would assign it the same probability as P, 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the conference?)**: Given the timing and the media attention surrounding the conference, I estimate a slightly lower probability for this event, perhaps around 0.55.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: The occurrence of both events is dependent, but not perfectly correlated. I estimate this probability to be around 0.40, as both events are likely but not guaranteed to happen together.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is where I need to apply the formula for the union of two events. The probability should be higher than either individual event but less than 1. I would estimate this to be around 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q and not_P occur?)**: This scenario is less likely as it requires Musk to make a statement without attending the event. I estimate this to be around 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: If Musk shows up, the likelihood of him making a statement increases. I would estimate this probability to be around 0.75.

In summary, I will ensure that the probabilities I assign adhere to the consistency rules outlined, particularly ensuring that the relationships between P and not_P, P_and_Q, P_or_Q, and other combinations align mathematically. The independence of events will also be a consideration, especially in how P and Q relate to each other.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.55,
P_and_Q: 0.40,
P_or_Q: 0.70,
Q_and_not_P: 0.15,
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.70 + 0.40 - 0.55 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.55 - 1, 0) <= 0.40 <= min(0.65, 0.55) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.55) <= 0.70 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.55) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.70 - 0.15 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.40 / 0.75 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

neg, and:  andor, cond consistency checks failed!
